newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan cloner cautiously welcomes new Apple system.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan cloner cautiously welcomes new Apple system.

text.p: A Taiwanese firm that has tied its fortunes to Apple Computer Inc's success cautiously welcomed on Thursday Apple's planned multi-platform operating system.
In May, Apple unveiled radical plans for a next-generation system, Rhapsody, which would run on both Apple and rival computers that use Intel Corp chips and Microsoft Corp Windows software.
But Taiwan's Umax Data Systems, which makes clones of Apple products, has some reservations about the plans.

"Obviously if Apple could develop Rhapsody with all its promises of being able to run on both PCs and Macs, that would be a big step in the right direction," Umax chairman Frank Huang told Reuters in an interview.
"But while we are cautiously optimistic that Rhapsody would be developed, nothing is for sure because Apple has cancelled plans before," Huang said.
In an ambitious attempt to prevent software companies from jilting its products, Apple said it would develop Rhapsody to allow Apple-based software to be converted for PCs powered by Intel chips.
But some programmers fear Rhapsody would not run the products they designed for the older Macs.
Apple so far has released operating system software that runs only on Apple-designed hardware.
Umax and its U.S. unit, Umax Computer Corp, are among several Asian manufacturers licensed to design and make Mac-compatible "clones" that run on Apple's current Macintosh Operating System.
In 1996, Apple abandoned a mired effort to revamp the Mac OS system. Instead, the company bought Next Software Inc and used its software as the foundation for Rhapsody.
For the past two years, Apple has scrambled to improve the Macintosh and set it apart from other personal computers.
Until 1995, Apple had relied on the famed ease-of-use of its products as a key selling point, but Microsoft's release of Windows 95 dealt a blow to that pitch.
In a bid to reclaim lost market share, Apple began licensing its operating system to companies like Umax.
But while Umax and other such cloning firms have thrived on selling Apple clones at a discount to Apple products, their success has meant dwindling Macintosh shipments for Apple.
However, Umax's Huang said his company has helped keep the embattled California-based firm alive.

"If it weren't for the clonemakers to promote its products, Apple would be even worse off right now," Huang said. "Several years ago Apple absolutely hated the idea of clones, but now it absolutely depends on clones."
Analysts have said the Macintosh operating system's share of the market has increased in recent months because of the success of the cloning companies.
